raw_text:
Serena ends Sania Mirza's dream
 
 Sania Mirza, the first Indian woman to reach the third round of a Grand Slam tennis event, has lost to women's favourite Serena Williams.
 
 The 18-year-old Mirza, who got a wild card entry into the Australian Open in Melbourne, lost to Williams 1-6,4-6 in the third round. Williams took just 56 minutes to defeat Mirza and sail into the fourth round. The only other Indian woman to win a match at a Grand Slam is Nirupama Vaidyanathan. Vaidyanathan made it to the second round of the Australian Open in 1998.
 
 Playing the biggest match of her life, Mirza made little impact on Williams in the early stages of the game. But the teenager showed more confidence in the second set and engaged the seventh-seeded Williams in some well contested rallies. Mirza, a junior Wimbledon doubles title winner, became the first Indian woman to reach the third round of a grand slam tennis event when she beat Hungarian Petra Mandula on Wednesday. "I'm really excited. I was confident but I didn't think it was going to be that easy," Mirza said after her second round win. "My aim was to win a round here. When I did that I was so relieved, there was no pressure." Tennis is not a particularly popular sport in India, but a number of Indians watched the live telecast of the match between Mirza and Williams. Mirza, who lives in the southern Indian city of Hyderabad known for producing a host of top Indian cricketers, turned professional two years ago. She says she was considered too small when she went for her first tennis classes as a six-year-old girl. "Then finally [the coach] called my parents up and said 'the way she hits the ball, I've never seen a six-year-old hit a ball like that'," Mirza told the Associated Press.

tinyllama:1.1b: Serena Williams, the reigning Australian Open champion, has beaten Sania Mirza in the third round of the Australian Open to set up a fourth-round clash against top seed Naomi Osaka.
The Indian tennis star, who was born and raised in Hyderabad but moved to Australia at a young age, had lost her previous two Grand Slam matches to Williams.
Despite playing some well-contested raills, Mirza failed to make an impact on the seven-time Australian Open champion's serve and received little support from the crowd.

Nonetheless, Mirza managed to pull off a notable win against Williams and become the first Indian woman to reach the third round of a Grand Slam tennis event since Nirupama Vaidyanathan did so in 1998.
Many Indians watched the match live on television, with tennis being less popular than cricket in India.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Serena Williams of the United States defeated her long-time rival and fellow American player, Venus Williams, to secure her place in the third round of the Australian Open tennis event in Melbourne.
The match was played on Friday afternoon with the 18-year-old Mirza from India also making a mark on the scene, coming up against the seven-time Wimbledon doubles champion, Williams.
It was clear that Serena Williams, a five-time Olympic gold medalist and World No.
1 in singles and women's doubles, was well accustomed to the pressure of a big match against a young and talented player.
In their early stages of the game, both Mirza and Williams showed signs of an exciting rivalry that could have been the stuff of legendary clashes.
However, as the match progressed, Serena Williams emerged victorious by winning all 10 sets in the match, including the crucial second set which Mirza eventually won in a closely contested battle.
Mirza was impressed with her opponent's ability to defend against pressure and continue to play at a high level after being outshined during the early stages of the match.
In response, Serena Williams expressed her admiration for Mirza's skill and dedication to tennis.
She acknowledged that she had been unable to break Mirza's serve in the early parts of the match but felt confident in her own abilities to defeat the young Indian woman.
The loss marks a significant setback for Serena Williams, who had already reached the fourth round of the Australian Open before this latest defeat.
Her coach, Patrick Mouratagel, has been working hard to turn around his team's fortunes, and he expressed optimism that they could regroup and improve their performance in the future.
Serena Williams has been known to be a tough opponent to face but Mirza will certainly hold no grudge against her if she decides to retire from tennis after her defeat by Williams.

In conclusion, this match between Serena Williams and her teenage Indian rival Mirza saw both players play with great passion and determination in an intense and closely contested battle that was ultimately won by the seven-time Wimbledon doubles champion, Serena Williams.
